dc:description.p:
This is a generic min() function that is passed a "template-pointer"
to a template that implements the less-than relation.
This function is much more usable than the "standard" min() function,
which is defined only on numerical arguments.

In a concise XSLT library there should be only one min() function -- the
generic one. When omitting the value for the template implementing less-than,
generic min() looks like and behaves identically to the "standard" min()
function.

html:div.p:
The generic min() function takes two arguments -- a node-set and a
template match node, and returns a minimum node -- one of the
"minimum nodes". This function has no apriori knowledge about
what is "less-than" and implements the "less-than" relation
by instantiating an external, user-defined template that must
match uniquely the value of the template-match node argument.

Because of the genericity of the function, it cannot return
the "minimum value", as the meaning of "value" for the
nodes of the node-set is not known in advance.
Also it may be the case when a comparison will not need
the notion of "value" in order to compare two nodes and
"value" for the nodes of a specific type may not exist
or may be too artificial.

When the template-match node is not provided, a default value
is used, which is matched by a template that implements the
standard "<" relation on numbers.
Therefore, both the "standard" min() and lowest() functions
are a special case of the generic min() function and could be
omitted from a concise template library.

exslt:doc.p: The return value of the min() function is a single-node nodeset, and this is a minimum node -- one of the "minimum nodes".
The node-set one of whose minimum nodes must be found.

This argument specifies a node with a unique namespace-uri to be matched by a caller-provided template that implements the "less than" relation.
This user-provided template must have the following parameters:
nodes -- a nodeset
n1-pos -- the position in $nodes of the first node to be compared
n2-pos -- the position in $nodes of the second node to be compared

The result that this user-provided template outputs is a text string that must be one of the following:
'true' -- if the first node is "less-than" the second
'false' -- otherwise
